thread.title: Jobseekers, software developer work doesn’t need a university degree
thread.title_full: Jobseekers, software developer work doesn’t need a university degree | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Melanie Burgess CareerOne deputy editor
title: Jobseekers, software developer work doesn’t need a university degree
text:
SOFTWARE developers are in such high demand in Australia that a keen interest and good attitude can be all it takes to get hired – no formal qualification needed.
In the digital age, almost every company or start-up requires coding of some sort.
NetEngine managing director Bruce Stronge says the shortage of software developers is not an issue of supply but demand.
“In eight years of running our business, it has become harder and harder (to find employees),” he says.
“More businesses are using software to solve their problems, hence the shortage has increased.”
About 14,600 new software and application development roles are forecast to be created in Australia between 2014 and 2019, Department of Employment figures find.
In the past two years, employment has grown 3 per cent in the occupational group, notably higher than the all-industries average of 1.9 per cent.
Developer Matthew Barram from NetEngine. Picture: Richard Waugh Source: News Limited
NetEngine software developer and team leader Matthew Barram took advantage of this growth when he decided to learn coding about two years ago. “From when I first started coding to when I got a job was less than six months,” he says.
“I started out with an online course for a few months, got some experience, got a referral to NetEngine and they said ‘We can’t find enough people, we want you on board’.”
Mr Barram says coding is a lot less complicated than it seems.
“We’re always looking for people and the last thing I care about would be a uni degree. It’s absolutely irrelevant in this sector as far as applying for jobs,” he says.
IS IT TIME TO QUIT YOUR JOB?
SECRETS TO NAILING THAT PROMOTION
“If someone had a month of full-time learning a new programming language that is in demand in Australia – Ruby on Rails or JavaScript – and they are able to talk and be a normal person, they will have no problem getting a job.”
Once in a job, the perks are plenty, too, as employers fight to retain their staff.
Mr Stronge says NetEngine appeals to its workers with a positive workplace, employee freedom and community involvement.
“If we can’t pay them a salary that Google and Facebook can, they are part of a society that is more exciting than renumeration,” he says.
PayScale data shows software developers earn between $45,000 and $93,000 a year.
At NetEngine, employees are allowed to work from home and in hours that suit them, coffee is free all day, beer is free all night, professional development is actively encouraged, the office is completely paperless and no one works on their birthday.
They are also encouraged to pursue personal projects and to participate in community and humanitarian initiatives such as Rails Girls, which inspires females to try coding, and Random Hacks of Kindness, which matches charities and social enterprises with developers who want to make a difference.
Random Hacks of Kindness will run in Brisbane on November 28-29.
For more information, visit rhokbrisbane.org
